title: Unit 3 (1.3) - Cell Processes and Energy Conversion

pieces1.definition: Process used by autotrophs which convert radiant energy into chemical energy.

pieces1.hint: Plants do this and we get to breath oxygen and eat sugar!

pieces1.definition: The process of breaking down glucose molecules and converting the energy into ATP molecules.

pieces1.hint: This process happens in the mitochondria, carried out by both plants and animals.

pieces1.definition: Elements or compounds that enter into a chemical reaction.

pieces1.hint: Examples include: carbon dioxide and water for photosynthesis

pieces1.definition: Elements or compounds produced or made by a chemical reaction.

pieces1.hint: Examples include: carbon dioxide and water for cellular respiration

pieces1.definition: Energy molecule created during cellular respiration to provide energy to the cell.

pieces1.hint: This is the 'currency' of the cell. Adenosine triphosphate.

pieces2.definition: The movement of ions and other molecules across cell membranes without the need of ATP.

pieces2.hint: Follows concentration gradient, does NOT need ATP.

pieces2.definition: An environment or solution that has less solute and more water than the cell.

pieces2.hint: Water would enter the cell when placed in this solution.

pieces2.definition: An environment or solution which contains more solute and less water than the cell.

pieces2.hint: Water would leave the cell and move into this environment.

pieces2.definition: This refers to there being a range in the amount of solute from high to low.

pieces2.hint: In passive transport, movement goes with THIS, flowing from high to low.

pieces2.definition: The movement of ions or other molecules across a cell membrane requiring the use of ATP energy.

pieces2.hint: Needs ATP to possibly move against the concentration gradient.
